title: Vendor and Internal Team Alignment: One System, Not a Battlefield
hook: SAP AMS fails fastest when internal IT, vendors, and business optimize against each other instead of the system.
idea: Coordination is an engineering problem. Define clear contracts, shared signals, and joint accountability so escalation becomes collaboration, not theater.

where_alignment_breaks: Vendors measured on SLA speed, not stability
Internal teams absorb integration pain without authority

interfaces_as_contracts: Defined success criteria (latency, error rate, volume)
Clear retry, compensation, and fallback rules
shared_accountability: Shared prevention backlog with owners and dates
Credits for elimination of systemic demand

levels.focus: Restore service using runbooks and workarounds
Identify and remove the root cause across teams
Adjust SLAs/SLOs, incentives, or ownership if patterns repeat

escalation_model.rule: Escalation level must match the nature of the problem — not the volume of emails.

single_truth: One incident timeline shared across parties
One set of metrics for impact and recovery

copilot_moves: Detect cross-team dependency early from signal correlation
Assemble neutral evidence packs for vendors
Track response vs dependency time separately

why_this_reduces_cost: Faster vendor response with better evidence
Structural fixes instead of contractual fights
anti_patterns_to_kill: Hiding systemic issues behind SLA compliance
metrics_that_expose_misalignment: Repeat issues crossing the same boundary
design_question: Where does responsibility end — and where does it silently disappear?
